dest.title: Where To Explore On A Yacht In Greece
dest.desc: Tips on where to go on your Greek vacation.

text.p: Greece's waters were designed to be visited by yacht. With dark pine trees mirrored off sparkling, blue seas and white beaches surrounding each coast, its complex shorelines conceal tremendous beauty behind every curve.

Thanks to hundreds of kilometers of pristine coasts, intimacy, and natural solitude are fundamental components of Greece's attractiveness. The temperate environment of the Eastern Mediterranean encourages yachting all year, with pleasant temperatures and splendid sunshine even in the fall months, all while maintaining the absolute safety that the Greek waters are renowned for. A cool summer wind permeates every one of the scores of charming islands and deserted islets to be explored, with a sweeping, clear sky. The combination of safe seas and a sense of isolation creates an unrivaled sailing experience.
If you are wondering about destinations to explore on a yacht in Greece, we have outlined a handy list that you can look into for your yacht vacation.

Mykonos is our overall winner since it offers the best of both worlds. It boasts the most beautiful beaches in Greece, with more than 20 stunning golden sand strips. These beaches appeal to a wide range of interests, including family beaches like Lia, fashionable beaches like Psarou, and calm beaches like AgiosSostis. Mykonos is located in the midst of the Aegean, making it quite easy to go either east or west if you want to later.

When it comes to dining out, there are both inexpensive (try Bandana) and premium (Nobu) restaurants featuring food from all over the globe. Large yachts may anchor in two or three bays, most notably Psarou and Ornos. Of course, the islands are well-known for their nightlife and are considered one of the top party locations in the Mediterranean.

Rinia is a little island immediately south of Mykonos that caters to a certain market. It only has two or three tiny bays that large boats may utilize, but the bays are relatively deep, providing excellent weather protection. It offers the cleanest oceans in the world and a vast, wonderful sandy beach that is shallow for miles. Apart from a few old remains and the houses that farmers use when they visit by boat to care for their animals and land, there isn't much on the island.

Because there aren't any taverns or restaurants on the island, you may dine right on the beach in perfect privacy. Rinia is approximately 45 minutes by boat from Mykonos, so if you want a bit of a change, go to Rinia, rest, and enjoy the peace and quiet. You may immediately return to Mykonos if you get bored.

This is really two islands located near Naxos and Mykonos. They have Rinia's calm and tranquil charm, yet there are just a few tiny hotels and tavernas. You can find some of the nicest coastlines in the Mediterranean on the upper island, as well as exquisite natural saltwater pools.

Finikas and FosFanari, two tiny rustic eateries, provide exclusively fresh fish obtained by local boats. Because there are just a few ferries and only two or three hotels, it is not extremely congested. If you want a beautiful sea to swim in, amazing beaches, plenty of fresh fish and lobsters, and relative seclusion, here is the place to go. A large harbor is available for boats up to 50 meters to anchor.

The Cyclades are a very appealing sailing destination, owing to their close vicinity to Athens and the wide range of activities they offer. Greece's signature globally is the juxtaposition of their immaculate white dwellings by the deep blue color of the sea, not to forget the colors of its flag. Since the distance between the two islands is so short, a yachting vacation may involve a lot of ports and coves in a short amount of time. You could even cruise to a new island every day, but each one will need careful scrutiny.

Further south, Milos provides stunning lunar vistas as well as dramatic beaches and coves accessible only by sail. It also contains one of the Mediterranean's biggest, virtually enclosed harbors, Adamas, which is safe in all types of weather and includes yacht-servicing facilities. If you visit Milos, the volcanic rock structures at Kleftiko just on the southern edge are a must-see.

The ability to charter a boat locally makes cruising around distant Dodecanese simpler. The Meltemia, especially in the summer, makes sailing a particularly appealing choice for skilled sailors since the waters are unrestricted. However, don't expect to arrive in one day. Almost all of the islands have airports, making travel from Athens simple.

Apart from Kastellorizo, these islands, like the Cyclades, are very near to one another, allowing you to explore a new one every day. Please remember that every island has much to offer to justify a longer visit. This group has a lot to offer, from Rhodes, the chain's hub, to the little islands of Arki, Lipsi, and Agathonisi. Leros, Kos, and, of course, Rhodes all have wonderful marinas that can accommodate boats of all sizes.

The densely forested Sporades islands are fantastic for yachting. The greenest of the three islands, Skiathos, Skopelos, and Alonissos, is a toss-up. Its ‘brother' Skyros, to the south, is pine-wooded and rugged, with the white Hora on a barren peninsula seen from miles away and a modern harbor. The distance between the islands is quite short, and you can easily visit all of them, as well as their smaller deserted cousins within the Sporades Marine Park.

Crete, the biggest of all Greek islands off the coast of Africa, is a fantastic sailing destination with enough to see and do. Unwind onboard and be mesmerized by the magnificent and dramatic hues of the water as you dock in secret coves and hidden beaches. When on land, see various snow-capped mountains, Minoan historical sites, green valleys, and beautiful beaches, dine at wonderful waterfront restaurants, and make lifelong memories.

Thassos is a lovely and peaceful island that is ideal for one full-day sailing adventure. See dolphins in Panagia, a preserved marine environment that is part of the Natura 2000 network on the southern shore, or view the spectacular rock formations and sea near Giola, farther east. Swim at Aliki and interact with Greek locals at Archodissa, a modest bar providing wonderful meals. Then proceed north to Paradise Beach along the shore. The lush islet called NisidaKinira is ideal for a quick exploring stop or a relaxing night at the little harbor of Thassos town's main port.

Begin your voyage in the shimmering Ionian Sea by stocking up on provisions at Zakynthos' harbor before touring tiny beaches and pausing by small harbors for lunch or supper. Don't miss the Blue Caves or the famed Navagio Beach, both of which can only be reached by boat. Then go north to the stunning island of Kefalonia, which requires a minimum of two days to really appreciate. aThe friendly Ithaca and the satellite islands around it await you next, followed by the magnificent Lefkada – don't hurry to the next destination and take time to enjoy its numerous wonderful beaches. Before arriving in Corfu, stop in at Paxi and Antipaxi, which are known for their beautiful beaches and quiet coves.

Chios is located on the eastern Aegean Sea, near Turkey. It's the fifth-largest of the islands around Greece, and it lacks the abundance of excellent sandy beaches seen on the top three. There are still beautiful locations to swim, including the Karfas and Maura Volia, and the water is very clean if a little cooler than usual due to its location within a stream of cold waters.

Instead, you'll discover wonderful medieval towns, as well as the castle and excellent museums, as well as the UNESCO World Heritage Site of Nea Moni, a Byzantine monastery founded in the 11th century. This island has a lot of history, so if you prefer historical civilizations, monasteries, and medieval towns, come here, rent a scooter, and have a look about.

Chios has a large airport, so you may ship the yacht ahead and fly in. There are very few international tourists on the island, but there are a lot of Greek visitors. Since there aren't as many high-end visitors or large yachts arriving, the cuisine is extremely fresh, and lobster is significantly cheaper than on Mykonos. Finally, you can even combine the tour with a charter flight to Turkey.

Although it is not technically an island, we are putting it on the list since it has lately gained a lot of popularity recently. Vouliagmeni is a small beach town 13 miles south of Athens. If you reside in Athens, this is the best area to swim since the water is pure. Mooring in the harbor with a breathtaking view of the biggest hotel south of Athens, Astir Palace Hotel.

This also has some of Greece's most costly real estate, making it very exclusive, and so many boats stop here for a few days before or after visiting Athens. If you have business in Athens, a helipad on top of the Astir Palace Hotel allows you to travel from the boat to the city every day. It's as though you're on an island rather than in a major city. It offers a beautiful sandy beach with excellent restaurants, particularly, and you may utilize all of the amenities.
We hope now you have some idea of where to explore on a yacht in Greece! Have fun on your next cruise on the beautiful waters of Greece.

dest.title: Top Destinations In The Mediterranean For Yacht Vacations
dest.desc: Trying to decide where to go on your vacation?

text.p: Is the Mediterranean calling you? Well, we are here to help you plan the finest yacht vacation this summer. We've compiled a list of standout itineraries and hand-picked choices of the top destinations in the Mediterranean for yacht vacations.

The Mediterranean has endless popular superyacht destinations, making it quite the treasure trove to visit, from the beautiful coastlines of Italy to the golden, sunny beaches of Balearics. It might be difficult to know where to start when planning a yacht charter trip in the Mediterranean, which is why we are here to help!
With the support of brokers and sailing experts, we've compiled this list of the top destinations in the Mediterranean for yacht vacations. Let's take a closer look now.

The Ionian Islands comprise of seven major Greek islands as well as several smaller islets. Each island stretches 50 miles south to north along Greece's west coast and has its own distinct appeal for charter passengers. Corfu is the biggest of the Ionian Islands, as well as a quite popular tourist destination. You can immerse yourself in the traditional culture of Zante Island or feel the charm of the Blue Grotto and Smugglers Cover in Zakynthos.

Sardinia is a blend of fashionable beach clubs, elegant shops, rich history, and natural beauty, making it one of the most spectacular Mediterranean yacht destinations. With a shoreline of secret coves and beautiful beaches, this yachting hideaway offers some of the greatest diving, snorkeling, and watersports. Celebrities promenade in luxury along the Porto Cervo beachfront, delivering a wonderful combination of elegance and beauty to the towns all along the Costa Smeralda. You can find some of the most enthralling anchorages in northern Sardinia.

Cala Granara in the Maddalenas, for example, has a bay in a wonderfully remote spot for superyachts to moor. Cala di Luna, set within a rocky promontory, is a beach connoisseur's dream, with spectacular snorkeling and adjacent ancient ruins for culture-lovers to investigate.

Sardinia's cuisine is hearty, tasty, and made with real Italian flare; local restaurants take pleasure in the availability of fresh ingredients from both land and sea -a fantastic source of inspiration for your yacht's chef to create unique, delicious meals on board.

The picturesque French island of Corsica, located near Sardinia and often visited as part of the same voyage, boasts some of the most stunning mountain landscapes in the Mediterranean.There are offshore anchorages and marina berthing to fully take in the environment, which is untamed and wild- yet unspoiled by man in parts. It has a French influence and is stunningly distinctive. The ports of Bonifacio and Calvi are known for their old town beauty and romance, while Lavezzi and Palombaggia are known for their stunning beaches and natural beauty. Corsica is a wonderful endpoint or stopover destination because of its strategic location between France and Italy.

With a long summer season, getting a yacht charter in Sicily allows you to enjoy a fantastic cultural experience while sampling the wonderful local cuisine. The superb sailing areas in this Italian island are studded with breathtaking scenery, including beautiful towns, black sand beaches, and towering volcanoes, all of which are best enjoyed by boat.

Palermo, Sicily's dynamic capital city and old harbor, is a perfect start or end location for a yacht charter vacation in Sicily, overlooking the spectacular Monte Pellegrino. To the east, hilltop Taormina exudes flair, with terraced cafés offering breathtaking views over the gorgeous Isola Bella beach, which is flanked by the majestic Mount Etna. The seven beautiful Aeolian Islands, located to the north, are home to a variety of attractions. Visit Lipari for lively eateries, visit desolate Volcano for hot springs, and sail by active Stromboli for a light display of flowing lava at a safe distance from the yacht.

Malta is a lesser-known yacht charter location, yet it is a wonderful Mediterranean jewel with a rich history. The Mediterranean sun will accompany you on your cruise to Malta, where charming harbors and ancient ruins nestle beside the stunning beaches and bays that are carved into the shoreline, only a short journey from Sicily. Gozo and Comino, two of the Maltese archipelago's 21 inhabited islands, provide some of the most isolated anchorages as well as some of the greatest watersports and diving spots. There are red sand beaches, rocky inlets, and crystal-clear seas that you can find here.

The Southern region of France is one of the most renowned yacht charter locations in the world. Chartering a boat on the French Riviera gives you the opportunity to have an ultimate luxury lifestyle, from the lively clubs on the beaches of St Tropez to the subtle grandeur of Monaco's casino culture. From the luxury of your own charter boat, see perched medieval villages, take in the Mediterranean sun, and savor gastronomic delights.

Dive into crystal blue seas off the isolated Porquerolles, which are dotted with hidden coves, from your yacht's swim platform. Further up the coast, the lovely sheltered anchorages of Villefranche-sur-Mer and Cap Ferrat are always popular, while anchoring off at the Cap d'Antibes to get a delicious lunch at the Hotel du Cap-Eden-Roc is a trendy option too. Make use of the watersports equipment before arriving in Antibes to wander the charming cobblestone streets, dine at Michelin-starred restaurants in Cannes, or dance all night in vibrant Juan Les Pins.

The Balearic Islands are a collection of four Spanish islands that each have their own distinct personality, and a yacht charter is an ideal opportunity to see everything these sailing grounds have to offer.

Mallorca is home to the ancient city of Palma, as well as hilltop communities, hidden coves, and lush mountaintops. There are several scenic sites where you may take in breathtaking views before dining at one of the many good restaurants onshore. Menorca's whitewashed beaches are ideal for mountain biking and kayaking in the sea. The island is known for its hidden jewels, such as the sandy CalaMacarelleta and its breathtaking seafood at waterfront restaurants. Formentera, Formentera's younger sister, is dotted with peaceful anchorages, ideal for a relaxing Balearic sailing adventure and sunset cocktails on the deck.

The white beaches and rocky coves of Ibiza invite you to rest throughout the day, but after the sun sets, be ready to dance with the finest as world-class DJs throw amazing parties in Ibiza Town. Spend the day sailing around EsVedra, a rocky island protrusion with a magnetic pull, and finish off at the Blue Marlin for a taste of Balearic sounds. Of course, you'd be remiss if you didn't include Beso Beach on your list; the beach bar and restaurant is a true Ibizan institution located only a short distance from the SesIlletes in Formentera. Nothing but pleasant feelings and cool audiences are to be expected.
Croatia has been one of the top destinations in the Mediterranean for yacht vacations and tourist destinations in recent years, thanks to its 1,200 islands.

Despite the popularity of locations like Dubrovnik, Split, and Hvar, it seems peaceful and remote from the deck of a luxury boat, with just 50 of its islands inhabited. On charter, it gives enough room for individuals wanting solitude and adventure.

The beautiful natural landscape is riddled with remains of a stormy past throughout its various islands, but since there is a lot to see, sticking to a charter schedule may be tough. Many people will take the time to explore Montenegro on the same vacation, which starts or ends at the Bay of Kotor and is known for its stunning natural beauty.

Despite the current concerns about sailing safety in the Eastern Mediterranean, Turkey continues to provide some of the most beautiful cruising areas for yacht charters. It has more coastline to explore compared to other Mediterranean nations and a cultural blend of Western and Eastern customs. The Turquoise Coast is named after the adjoining blue-green colors of its sea and the horizon. It is widely recognized for its beautiful beaches and breathtaking mountain scenery. Guests can enjoy Fethiye's lively port, Marmaris' bustling town, and Lüdeniz's protected lagoon.

During your journey, you should stop at Lebessos Winery. This restaurant, housed in a 400-year-old stone hamlet in the Kayakoy town (that has been abandoned since 1923), is Fethiye's gourmet dining leader. The venue receives bonus points for its cab service, which eliminates the need to schedule a shuttle.

The native food is traditional and wonderfully prepared; try the levissi chicken with spicy yogurt, soft lamb kleftiko, or honey-drenched figs. In addition, the restaurant has a wine cellar where you may experience Turkish wines.

The Amalfi Coast, located just south of ancient Naples and embellished with technicolor cities, perched villages, and interesting isles, provides unlimited choices for a stunning boat charter itinerary. Sorrento remains popular due to a network of elegant stores and sophisticated bars, while the CliffsidePositano exemplifies a wealthy resort town with breathtaking views on land and at sea. The region's namesake, Amalfi, is steeped in romanticism and known for its great beaches and lemon production. Cruise farther away to relax in the hot springs on the little island of Ischia, while vistas towards the towering cliffs of Capri are indeed a joy to see from a boat.

Eat traditional food prepared with fresh flavors and local products ripened and sweetened by the sun, a highlight of a yacht vacation in Italy. Naples, the birthplace of pizza, is the ideal location to sample the famous margherita. The Amalfi Coast is known for its lemons, which may be found in cooling gelatos and, obviously, the wonderfully sweet native limoncello.

When exploring the top destinations in the Mediterranean for yacht vacations, you should make a list of all the places you want to hit and go for it. There may not be another chance to explore the beautiful paradise points of the areas around the Mediterranean, so make the most of it!

dest.title: Best Places To Visit On An Italy Yacht Charter
dest.desc: Learn the secrets of an Italian vacation.

text.p: A yacht charter vacation is certainly one of the finest, most luxurious, and enjoyable ways to enjoy the breathtaking islands, beaches, cities, and villages in any country, and Italy is no exception. The European country boasts mesmerizing landscapes, such as sandy beaches, volcanoes, hills, verdant planes, and many varied, culturally rich islands. If you take a yacht charter in Italy to explore all the varied locations, you will be able to move freely, at your convenience, and explore your favorite beaches at a pace that suits you and your loved ones.
So, without any ado, let's take a look at the best places you can visit in Italy on a yacht charter!
The Best Places to Visit with a Yacht Charter in Italy
Here are the best islands, cities, and coasts you must visit in Italy on your yacht charter vacation:

Sardinia is a paradise-like picture-perfect coastline that lies in the middle of the Mediterranean Sea. About 12 miles south of Corsica, Sardinia is home to many spectacular islands and beaches of the Archipelago of La Maddalena. You can explore castle and fort ruins, stunning churches, and magnificent galleries and museums.

With more than sixty islands, rocks, and islets, you can also find many sandy beaches with clear shining seas. These unspoiled and utterly beautiful spots are excellent for yachting and sailing. Southern Sardinia has shallow beaches, excellent water sports conditions, and hot weather. Moreover, many nearby cities house Michelin-starred eateries to fulfill your fine dining dreams.

Northern Sardinia has Porto Cervo, a seaside resort known as a superyacht and chartered yachts hub. It features many eateries and shops for you to explore and have a fun time. It houses an eclectic mix of fishing villages, beautiful villas, and high-end boutiques. You will witness the spectacular pink granite coastline, dazzling, pristine beaches, and sheltered anchorage and coves when exploring Sardinia.

Sicily is the largest island in the Mediterranean Sea and is also the country's biggest island. Not only is Sicily blessed with an expansive landscape, but it also has some pretty diverse landforms, such as the dynamic volcanic and mountainous scenery, the flowering meadows, and the beautiful crystal blue seas. The beaches offer many water sports and partying opportunities.

What makes Sicily stand out as one of the most culturally diverse places in Italy is that it has been invaded numerous times over the years by the Greeks, Romans, Arabs, Phoenicians Spaniards, and Normans due to its strategic location. Each of these occupants left behind their cultural influences that have given Sicily its blended yet distinctive culture and architecture. The UNESCO World Heritage Sites and city streets of Palermo, the capital of Sicily, are a must-visit for all yacht travelers.

The Aeolian Islands - Vulcano, Lipari, Stromboli, Panarea, Alicudi, and Filicudi - are in the middle of the Tyrrhenian Sea, about fifteen miles from the coast of Sicilia. They feature volatile mountains and stunning back beaches made from volcanic soil. With your yacht charter in Italy, you can explore the island archipelagos at your own pace. The Aeolian Islands will also offer many scenic spots where you can moor the yacht overnight.

Even though the Aeolian Islands are quite dramatic, they are not as well-known as Sicily or the Gulf of Maples, making them the ideal vacation spot for families looking for a less touristy spot. The dramatic beaches and islands have towering cliffs, striking volcanoes, fertile fields, and fallen Roman-Greco temple statues. You can take your yacht to a quiet beach and snorkel or have a relaxing night under the starry sky.

The ports of the islands feature charming eateries and bars. Meanwhile, the interiors have contrasting landscapes, crystal clear water bays, active volcanoes, simple white-painted houses, isolated reefs, and archaeological sites that are dramatic and beautiful.

Naples is one of the most renowned and oldest inhabited sites in the world. It features many modern and ancient treasures. The Gulf of Naples houses Sorrento, a picturesque town with a narrow ravine flowing through its historical landscape. The town features numerous old shops selling local Sorrento lemon liqueur, ceramics, and lacework. It also houses many striking hotels that offer an enticing combination of five-star service and quaint old-world charm.

You can unwind in Sorrento's serene parks, enjoy some gelato ice cream, and stroll the streets while having local food. You can also find pretty souvenirs made with fine wooden marquetry boxes. Meanwhile, Naples is steeped in history and offers delicious culinary delights. You have to see the art of San Lorenzo Maggiore and the veiled figures of Museo Cappella Sansevero.

Furthermore, the Gulf of Naples also includes the idyllic Capri, known for its luxurious shopping opportunities. When you visit Capri, you can find unique shops that carry everything from pottery and accessories to shoes and fabrics. The town also houses many deluxe restaurants, the Gardens of Augustus, and elegant caf's. The lesser-known town of Ischia is known for its immaculate landscaped gardens, a magnificent Aragonese castle, and relaxing thermal spas.

If you're looking for some truly unique landscapes, you must visit the Amalfi Coast on your yacht charter in Italy. Rocky cliffs with winding and twisting roads, secluded bays, and small villages offer a beautiful view of the clear blue ocean. Moreover, the coast also boasts verdant Mediterranean flora that colors the slopes of the adjoining cliffs and hills. The coast also houses world-renowned towns, such as Ravello, Amalfi, and Positano.

When traveling to the Amalfi Coast, you will have the opportunity to visit Pompeii, a striking archaeological site of a thriving Roman town that became a victim of the Mount Vesuvius volcanic eruption in AD79. Since the whole town was covered with 25 meters deep ash, blocking air and moisture, it ensured the preservation of the town relics. These relics reflect the remarkable intricacies of daily life in the old days.

Moreover, you can enjoy authentic Italian coffee at one of the many quaint caf's in Positano. You must also visit the Church of Santa Maria Assunta before you head to other islands. If you want to explore beautiful beaches and find shaded coves for water sports, you can visit the hotspots, such as Spiaggia di Tordigliano.

How can one not include Venice in the list of places you must visit in Italy on your yacht charter? After all, it's a beautiful and world-renowned city with incredible architectural attractions listed as UNESCO World Heritage Sites. You can take part in the annual carnival and take the famous gondola ride on the Grand Canal. You can also shop for genuine Vatican souvenirs, such as hand-blown Murano glass. Visit historic sites like the Palazzo Ducale and Basilica di San Marco.

Meanwhile, the Adriatic Sea is a striking destination you can choose to begin or end your charter vacation. You can cruise to the impressively beautiful Istrian peninsula and the Dalmatian coast, where the islands feature breathtaking, untouched beaches with shallow and clear water. You can also find plenty of scuba diving sites around the area.

When traveling on a yacht in Italy, you must take your yacht charter to the Italian Riviera. It features many notable attractions, such as San Basilio, the Russian Orthodox Church in Sanremo. The waterfront features varied eateries that offer an outdoor setting and sunbathing areas, where you can take in the verdant vegetation that borders the pale sandy beaches and vibrant blue seas.

If you love medieval architecture, you will certainly love the enchanting La Pinga. You must also visit the museums that line the La Spezia, a city with a comprehensive maritime history that it displays in its Technical Naval Museum. You can also marvel at St. George's Castle, which offers panoramic views of the sea and features the Archaeological Museum. For art lovers, the Amedeo Lia Museum features some beautiful art as it is established on the site of an old convent.

The Italian Riviera also houses a small port town known as Portofino. It's a quaint town that features Museo del Parco sculptures and a 16thcentury castle and museum known as Castello Brown. You will also find well-known luxury international brands that you can shop from to find gifts for your loved ones back home.

You can also visit the Cinque Terre villages that are UNESCO World Heritage Sites. These villages offer stunning views of colorful shops and houses that you can enjoy from your charter yacht. You can also traverse them on foot and shop in the small boutiques or grab a bite from the local caf's. You can also cruise to one of the bays accessible by water for a fun-filled afternoon of snorkeling and swimming.

Tuscany boasts pristine wilderness and a mesmerizing coastline. Since most of the coast is only accessible by sea, it offers you some privacy for sunbathing during the day and partying under the stars. You can swim and snorkel among the colorful fish for hours or be at peace with nature on Capraia. You can also go to Elba to enjoy hiking along the trails that offer views of the oldest ruins on the island.

Now that you know about all the breathtaking coasts, villages, and cities you can visit on a yacht charter in Italy, make sure to include them on your itinerary. These places offer a comprehensive Italian experience, with delicious local food, specialty drinks, souvenirs, archeological sites, diverse landscapes, and so much more.

dest.title: Yacht Care & Maintenance Tips
dest.desc: Increase the lifespan of your boat.

text.p: If you live near a major body of water, a yacht is your passport to a vacation filled with excitement and adventure. On the wide sea, a boat results in freedom. It may bring you outside at moments in the year where you may not other consider being outside on the sea.

That is why, to maintain a boat and ensure that it is operating for a long time to come, adequate boat maintenance is required. Under moderate to heavy usage, all boats suffer a battering. Depending on the kind of waters and weather circumstances, they may be exposed to various hazards that threaten to collapse or ground them on the shore if proper precautions are not taken.

Boat maintenance, thankfully, is simple with a little knowledge and experience. Knowing the kind of repairs and maintenance your yacht needs and how to care for it can go a long way in ensuring a longer lifespan for your boat.
Let's take a closer look at some yacht care and maintenance tips.

During typical usage, fiberglass hulls may take a battering. Most issues arise over time when many impacts and debris repeatedly strike the same spot, eroding the hull's integrity. Cleaning may help remove some wear and tear or buildup, but we have found that fiberglass reconditioners go much farther.

This is referred to as a fiberglass reconditioning compound, and it can usually eliminate some of the oxidation stains and watermarks that may damage the boat's hull over time. Many compounds additionally cover the hull with a protective layer that deflects water and oil during regular operation.
To safeguard the boat during the season, follow this step in your pre-season yacht maintenance program.

Your yacht will appear gleaming and new after a thorough cleaning. More significantly, it will preserve the hull in excellent condition for a much longer period of time. This is particularly true in the case of boats that are utilized in saline water.

When it's time to wash the boat, make sure you use the right cleaning agents that won't harm the surfaces. These treatments are often intended to remove common dirt and germs that accumulate over time. Some goods will be designed expressly for usage with specific kinds of water.

Even if you aren't using your batteries, they will deteriorate over time. Regular entropy causes power drains and leaks. If you neglect these concerns, you might end yourself stranded on the open sea with no lights or electricity.

A battery check should be carried out at least once per season as part of routine boat maintenance. A voltage meter may be used to detect how much charge is remaining in batteries. Determine how much charge the batteries typically consume during a particular season ahead of time. Replace batteries that are going low to be safe.
Examine all connections to your batteries as well. Clean these connections to ensure that the power gets to where it's required the most.

Typical boat maintenance during the regular season includes cleaning the boat down following one or two trips on the water. This will aid in the removal of usual grime and muck accumulation while also simplifying off-season cleaning.

Whenever you're cleaning the boat, be certain to use freshwater. For most surfaces, spray the boat with the hose. As a spot cleaner, utilize fresh water from the tap in a bucket with cleaning soap to wash away any problematic places.
Make sure the water you use is of good quality. Most tap water is safe to drink, but be careful of contaminants and minerals that might harm the surface of your boat.

Electrical wires on a yacht, like batteries, may deteriorate with time. Physical injury, as well as dirt and filth, are typical reasons. You should inspect these lines on a regular basis and make any and all required replacements or repairs.

When anything fails to operate or switch on during a typical boat operation, the electrical wires are likely faulty. Anything that isn't regulated by mechanical systems is prone to failure. Cleaning power cables is an excellent approach to prevent these problems, but all wires ultimately need to be replaced.
Another instrument for inspecting the condition of these cables is a voltmeter.

It's easy to believe that your boat will work flawlessly every time you bring it out on the lake. Most individuals make that assertion after purchasing a new boat or doing routine maintenance or upgrades on it. Regrettably, difficulties might arise at any moment.

It's a good idea to start examining your boat on a regular basis. Some checks should be performed on a more regular basis than others. For example, before taking your boat out, you may quickly examine the hull for apparent concerns. Every time you use it, you should do this.

Checking the wiring, engine, pumps, fluids, and controls should be done at least once per season before operating the yacht. An inspection can help you determine what sort of yacht maintenance is necessary while also preventing severe problems from arising.
<li>Clean Your Windows with A Window Cleaner

If the windows get excessively filthy, a decent window cleaner may help a lot. Cleaning windows that are directly in the spray line as the yacht passes through the water should be on the yacht maintenance checklist. The majority of the windows at the bow and waterline will fall into this category.

If you wish to stay loyal to the boat's demands, specialty cleaners are available. Certain window home cleaners work for some folks, but their effectiveness is hit or miss. If you're unsure, a little trial and error can help you figure out what actually works for you and the boat.

If your boat sinks, boat upkeep is meaningless. Bilge pumps are normally provided to pump the water out of the boat's interior to prevent the boat from sinking. These pumps might help save lives in bad weather or severe seas.

Bilges, like any other form of pump, need regular maintenance. Electrical and mechanical systems have a high failure rate. Debris and items, in particular, may become stuck in a pump's internal workings, thus stopping the flow of water.

Before using the pump for the season, make sure it's in good working condition by testing it. An electrical problem might be indicated by a failure to startup or function correctly. A mechanical problem might be indicated by strange sounds or an absence of pumping motion. Before putting the boat out, you may have to fix a defective component or replace the complete unit in both circumstances.

Unless you are a skilled mechanic or have decades of boat care knowledge, there's a strong chance you'll need to hire a proper professional to inspect and repair your boat at some point. This is especially true with regard to repairing and upgrading the boat's more complicated inner workings, such as its engines.

Professional technicians are typically able to identify problems before they become big difficulties. They'll also assist you in protecting the yacht during the off-season and fine-tuning your normal boat maintenance to meet the demands of your boat.

Feel free to browse around for alternative mechanic choices when it is time for major repair or update. Consider the experience and the services they provide, as well as the fees they charge. While it's tempting to choose the costliest mechanic, it's not always essential or even advisable.

During the off-season, most boats sustain a great deal of damage. Yachts like the spring and summer seasons since there isn't any ice, snow, or extreme cold to harm them. Depending on the area, you may need to find out ways to winterize your boat to keep it safe from extreme weather conditions.

To keep their boats for the winter, some customers choose indoor storage or climate-controlled docks. If you're changing to a private dock for the winter, these alternatives normally entail monthly fees or a lump sum payment. If you generally keep the boat on your own property, commercial solutions such as tarps and backyard buildings may be available.

If done regularly and properly, proper yacht maintenance will keep the boat healthy and happy for many years. The most common stumbling block is simply finding the drive to do the essential maintenance on the boat.

There's no better time than the present to establish your own regimen. Summer is coming rapidly. As a result, most individuals will be getting ready for summer aquatic activities in no time. Get a head start on that upkeep!

dest.title: The Top 10 Yachting Destinations
dest.desc: Figure out whare to go on your yachting vacation.

text.p: Picture this: the sun is beating down on you as a fresh breeze ruffles your hair. You lean back and enjoy the gentle rocking motion of your yacht in one of the world's most beautiful sailing destinations. Doesn't that sound amazing?

You can have that experience and more when you know where to go. After all, you didn't buy your yacht to take it on a local trip once a year. Be adventurous and get out there! Enjoy the experience of sailing around the world.
To help you plan your next dream yachting trip, here are the top ten yachting destinations. Visit these to find the beauty, relaxation, and fun you've been craving.

If you're looking for some beautiful buildings and are an architecture fan, the French Riviera has gorgeous towns lining its coast. The bright colors and bustling life complement its subtle vintage feel.

If you're feeling adventurous, you can even make your way to the beautiful, natural health retreat nearby: Monaco. You can also stop by the coast for one of its many lively festivals throughout the year.
If you want to avoid the rainy weather, you should sail here from late spring to early fall.

If you want to travel through a breath-taking natural landscape, you should consider the Norwegian Fjords. This area, formed by glaciers, is full of peaceful blue and green waters. You can also view the quaint, rustic villages nearby and stop in for lunch.
If you're wanting sunshine, June through August is the best time to travel here. If you're wanting to catch a glimpse of the Northern lights, you should sail here between October and March.

The Dalmatian Coast is speckled with stretching, sandy beaches and dotted with islands just waiting to be explored. Get out and swim, or enjoy the carved rock cliff sides decorated with lush greenery.

Get the best of both worlds with nature on all sides and ancient architecture abutting the shore. If you want to enjoy the experience without the crowds, plan your trip here in May, September, or October, to avoid the tourist season but still have warmer weather.

Between the Sporades islands, off the east coast, and sailing near the beauty of Santorini, there's lots to love about Greece! The lush, green plant life and hidden coves on the islands lend their beauty and provide a sense of adventure as you travel through the many islands.

When closer to the mainland, you can see the picturesque cliffside with restaurants and buildings rising out of it. Like Croatia, you should plan to visit in May, September, or October to avoid the crowds.

Sail the shores of Italy and experience a historical, architectural wonder. Mountains and cliffs stretch over blue waters, spread with greenery and buildings old and new. Stop by one of the many small towns to enjoy the atmosphere and food, or swim at one of its beaches.

Walk the cobbled streets and smell the sea air while enjoying a glass of wine or a short shopping spree. The best time to visit is in Spring and Fall, as the temperatures will be more moderate and the crowds will be gone.

This gorgeous group of islands has it all: marine life, natural, untouched beauty, and warm, sunny weather. Indonesia has about 17,500 islands to explore, and these are some of the best. You can go diving and see the ocean life up close, including coral reefs.
There are hiking spots and locations where you can watch exotic animals from a distance. To avoid the currents and rain, the best time to visit is from April to August.
The Maldives has been known for its stunning geography for a long time. Made of 1,100 islands, it covers a wide expanse of the Indian Ocean and offers recreation along with its relaxing scenery.

You can watch dolphins playing and jumping out of the water or dive down deep to see ocean life, including sharks and whales. Additionally, jet skiing and other water activities are allowed here, on the beautiful sea in the sunshine. It's best to visit during the dry season, between November and April.

If you're interested in biodiversity and a stunning, South American getaway, the Galapagos Islands are a great destination for your next yachting trip. Get up close and personal with amazing animal life such as sea lions and giant tortoises.

The hot, rainy season that starts in December can be the best time to break out your yacht, as the ocean is the smoothest for sailing. Starting in January, there are fewer tourists, and you'll have the place to yourself! Enjoy snorkeling, diving, hiking, kayaking, or surfing in one of the most amazing natural locations in the world.

If you are a more adventurous sailor, you may want to visit the Antarctic Gateway, where the rough Drake passage takes skill to navigate even on a good day. Once you get past the rough passage, where cold and warm water meet and rough winds have beat against many boats, you'll see the natural glacial beauty of the Antarctic.

As you pass by Chile and Argentina on your way there, however, you'll see natural ice formations and national parks, scenic mountains against the cold waters, and many small port towns where you can stop and refuel with some delicious South American cuisine. February is one of the warmest months for this area, and you can still see some whales in March.

Queensland, Australia may not be the first place you think of to go yachting, but it's one of the most rewarding. From Moreton Bay, a popular spot for diving and swimming, to Whitsundays, which includes the well-known Hamilton Island, there are endless places to explore and recreate in the warmth of Australia's southern coast.

It's also home to the Great Sandy Strait, a picturesque destination with clear water that allows you to see the wildlife, including whales, dolphins, sea turtles, and dugongs, a manatee-like animal. The best time to visit this area is January through March for the warmest weather and the calmest ocean.
Hopefully, you've learned about some great options for your next sailing adventure that were provided for us by Lana from CrowdsourcedExplorer.com.
Be sure to get tips from locals before you go! You want to know all the most beautiful and fun spots to visit, and locals often know about things the tour guides won't tell you.

dest.title: Should I Use A Yacht Broker?
dest.desc: Boat brokers usually charge a 10% commission. The question is, should you pay this fee, or sell it yourself?

text.p: Boat brokers usually charge a 10% commission. The question is, should you pay this fee, or sell it yourself?

Unlike with real estate, where most houses are sold via the MLS system, there is no one central listing site for boats. Buyers find boats through all types of methods. You can do a “For Sale By Owner” listing, where you post your listing on as many sites as you can, but it will cost you hundreds of dollars and take a lot of time and effort. Brokers pay a fixed monthly fee to each site and then can add an unlimited number of listings, many times using an automated system, so it is easy for them to promote your boat on all of the top boating marketplaces.

For listings on Yachts.com, I have tried advertising yachts for sale on these types of sites, and currently pay over $500/month to do this, but I have not found the response to be that great. For lower-priced boats though, people tell me Craigslist and Facebook marketplace generates a lot of buyers.

One advantage a broker has is they can get your boat listed in YachtWorld.com, which is the biggest site for this sort of thing and is for brokers only. A broker can also co-broke your listing, which means other brokers throughout the country will also try to find a buyer for your boat.

The biggest advantage of a broker is that they can market your boat both nationally and locally. Their brokerage already is getting new potential buyers every day looking for a boat like yours. They also can promote it in the same geographic area where your boat is located, and help the buyer through the sale process so everything goes smoothly.

If you are not in a rush and have the time to deal with it, it is worth trying to sell your boat on your own. But for the typical seller, I would recommend using a broker, as that way it has a much higher chance of getting sold.

dest.title: Self-Driving Boat - Version #1
dest.desc: Watch the video of the first test of our autonomous boat.

text.p: The video above is the first test of our autonomous boat (as described in our previous article posting about self-driving boats). Keep in mind it took James Dyson 5,127 tries to invent his revolutionary vacuum cleaner, and Thomas Edison made over 1,000 unsuccessful attempts at inventing the light bulb before it finally worked. So we are just getting started.

The model boat in the video is made entirely using a 3D printer. This demo version does not yet have the self-driving part; instead it is remote controlled. Being able to control it remotely is the first step to adding the autonomous part. The next version will carry a cell phone, which will control the boat and allow the user to remotely log in to enter a destination for the boat to go to.

The body of the boat is made of PLA white plastic and was printed on an Anet A8+ 3D printer in one single print. The model itself was designed with Python and OpenSCAD by my programmer (Peter Chervenski) in a Jupyter notebook. He initially modeled only the motor cases and the propellers to ensure a perfect fit and also to measure how much current the motor draws with the propeller on. With that info, he selected two LM317 regulators for each motor (adjusted to output 12V), one 7805 regulator for the NodeMCU, and two TIP31C MOSFET transistors used as relays.

He then built a crude model of the electronics on a breadboard and once it worked, soldered the components on a PCB board to make it permanent. The next step was programming the NodeMCU using a computer over the USB port. The program simply turns on/off two pins on the NodeMCU in response to the command it receives over Bluetooth.

For the remote control part, he wrote an Android app in Java which shows 3 buttons "left", "right" and "both". Touching a button turns on the motor, and lifting the finger from the button turns the motor off. Finally, he added an on/off switch for the whole thing, installed and glued the battery box to the body, then the PCB board, connected all wires and it was done.

One of the biggest problems with all of this is that weeks worth of work can be ruined by putting the boat in the water and having the electronics get wet. For the boat you see in our video, duct tape was used in an effort to reduce the probability water would get inside. But that did not work very well (plus a piece of the duct tape got caught in the propellers, making noise) so we need to find a better solution.
Our next version of the boat will actually drive itself, and hopefully not sink.

One of the main benefits of yacht sharing is that, like with a boat club, everything is handled for you. You don't need to pay for marina fees or insurance, and you don't do any maintenance. It is like renting a car, you just show up and drive.

Some companies, such as SailTime, let you choose to be either a "Member" or an "Owner". As a Member, you get to share usage of a specific sailboat for a monthly fee. As an Owner, have a partial share of the yacht, and the company will manage it for you by renting it out for charters, giving you a return on your investment and allowing you also to use the boat yourself.

dest.title: Self-Driving Boats
dest.desc: Autonomous navigation uses AI to drive the boat. Like a Tesla.

text.p: As I wrote about in a recent article, electric boats are growing in popularity, as they are silent, energy efficient,, and have zero pollution. But what makes a Tesla car special is not just that is electric, it is that it can drive itself. Although there are not any boats available to general public that do this, there are a bunch of new companies working on it.

Autonomous navigation (in a Tesla or boat) all comes down to using artificial intelligence, which is a good fit for electric vehicles. Now that electric boats have gained some acceptance, the self-driving part is more easily achievable. An example is Roboat (shown in the photo above), which operates in the canals of Amsterdam with no captain or crew.

One advantage of self-driving vessels is they can be up to 80% smaller, making them cheaper to build, easier to navigate, and less expensive to power. They don't need space for the typical human amenities such as bathrooms, decks, pilothouses, bunks, and kitchens.

Owning a self-driving boat is not just about saving money, it is also about safety. Ship collisions account for over 1/3 of all maritime accidents, with most of these being caused by human error. Autonomous marine systems never get tired, providing obstacle detection and collision avoidance 24/7.

Using AI does not necessarily mean a human isn't involved. A captain can use this advanced technology to get critical alerts and make more well-informed decisions to prevent accidents. All of this is especially useful on cargo ships, which account for 90% of global trade.
The image above is from Sea Machines, which offers a system that allows a cargo ship to be piloted remotely from a PC. You can even set up a command center to control a fleet of ships.

Other companies developing autonomous boats include SEA-KIT, ZeaBuzz, SeaBubbles, Metal Shark, Rolls Royce, Buffalo Automation, Artemis Technologies, IBM, Liquid Robotics, SailBouy, Saildrone, Unleash Future Boats, KONGSBERG, L3Harris, Open Ocean Robotics, and Orca AI.
Soon, you will be able to add Yachts.com to that list. Yes, that is right, we are working on developing our own self-driving boat. So far we are only at the model stage, see below:

The prototype shown in this photo does not float, as it is much easier to test things out of the water. It uses an Android phone as a brain, a GPS sensor, 3D printed parts, and Python for programming. The phone acts as a server, allowing us to go to a private web page, enter the GPS coordinates for a destination, and have the “boat” automatically go there.

The main problem with this design is that, of course, it is not a boat. A boat needs to deal with moving in water and protecting the electronics from getting wet. And if it gets stuck, we either have to start all over and build a new one, or potentially drown swimming out to retrieve it. But once we make a little more progress, here’s our potential design:

This high-tech preview has probably whipped you into a frenzy, wondering how you can get your hands on our marvelous nautical creation. Because we would be overwhelmed with business, and want to focus on research and development, we are not taking any pre-orders (sorry to disappoint you). But, stay tuned to our site to see the next version, launching in a few weeks.

dest.title: Boat Clubs
dest.desc: A boat club offers unlimited access to a fleet of boats for a flat monthly membership fee.

text.p: A boat club offers unlimited access to a fleet of boats for a flat monthly membership fee. No need to worry about all the costs and hassles associated with owning a boat; the boat club does it all for you: maintenance, slip fees, seasonal hauling and storage, insurance, cleaning, and more. You get the convenience of simply going to the marina and heading out on the water.

The cost of joining a boat club varies by location, but a rough estimate might be that you would pay a $5,000 initiation fee and then $400/month. This gives you the ability to use their boats in your local marina, and also the boats at all their other locations. Many boat clubs also have member-only social gatherings, making it a good way to meet other boaters.

Don't get a boat club confused with a yacht club (sometimes known as a "sailing club"). A yacht club is like an exclusive country club, with a clubhouse and an attached bar/care/restaurant where members socialize. Yacht clubs also host regattas and races. Unlike a boat club, they are not in the business of rental/sharing boats.

There are several drawbacks to using a boat club instead of buying your own boat. Many clubs only allow you to take the boats out from 9am to 5pm, and not all boats allow fishing. It also can be hard to get reservations at peak times (weekends and holidays).
Some of the largest boat clubs include::
Freedom Boat Club - Over 285 locations in the USA, Canada, and France.
Carefree Boat Club - Around 100 locations in the USA, Canada, British Virgin Islands, Panama, and Philippines.
Your Boat Club -Minnesota, Illinois, and Wisconsin.
Dream Boat Club -France, Sweden, UK, and Spain.
Nautical Boat Club - Georgia, South Carolina, Tennessee, Texas, and Wisconsin.
With many of these companies, each location is an independent franchise, so the level of service can vary greatly. Make sure to look up reviews for your specific location before joining.

dest.title: Electric Boats
dest.desc: There are several new companies that want to become the Tesla of the ocean.

text.p: There are several new companies that want to become the Tesla of the ocean. Electric boats are growing in popularity because they eliminate the harmful pollution and noise of conventional fossil-fuel motors, allowing you to enjoy the sounds of nature and the water. In addition to helping prevent climate change, you also save on maintenance because there are fewer moving parts, and no winterization is needed. Potential customers can either buy a new electric boat, like the one shown in the photo above from Voltaire (also check out their competitors such as Silent-Yachts, Zinboats, Candela, X Shore, and ArcBoats) or go with a company such as Torqeedo, Oceanvolt, Pure Watercraft, or Stealth Electric Outboards that offers electric outboard motors to convert your existing boat. To help keep Boston Harbor clean, there is even a company named Boston Electric Boats that rents out only electric boats.

Another advantage is that electric engines are around 75% cheaper to run, in terms of the cost of the electricity vs the gasoline. And like with a Tesla, they have almost instant acceleration, which is something many boaters appreciate, while the complete absence of oil residue, toxic fumes, and noise pollution is something the marine life will appreciate.

Many electric boats are built for slowly driving around a harbor or lake, while others such as the Zin Boat can go up to 35mph, with a range of 80-100 miles (powered by a BMW i3 battery, it recharges using a 110V or a 220V plug, making life much easier). Sailboats can also be a good fit for an electric motor, as it is only needed for short durations, like when there is no wind, or for heading into the harbor or marina. And in Norway and Finland, electric ferries have been successfully running for several years.

The first electric boat was built by German inventor Moritz von Jacobi in 1839 in Russia. It had a top speed of 3 miles per hour, was 24 feet in length, and carried 14 passengers. From the 1880s to the 1920s electric boats became popular but were eventually replaced by gas-powered motors. The recent resurgence is due to dramatic advances in battery technology and solar power, as well as the growing concern about global warming. Just like with the electric car market, adoption has started off slow due to high prices and limited availability, but sales are projected to reach $10 billion by 2026.

Another advantage of electric boats is that they can much more easily be autonomously controlled, as compared to a standard boat. This means, like with a Tesla, it can use artificial intelligence to be 'self-driving'. We will explore that topic further in our next article.
